segments.text: I think it was about 15,000 people pulled out of there that day.
And we did not have a single accident other than the one I described in doing that.
And this was accomplished, if my memory serves me correctly, with one heavy helicopter squadron of CH-52s, two
H-34 squadrons and we had a Huey squadron which was really used in reserve.
So there was a small number of Marine helicopter pilots.
Earned their pay.
And my hat's off to them.
They did a tremendous job.
And, of course, the Marines that went into the embassy there did a tremendous job.
They did not have a single solitary casualty, nor did they kill anybody.
They were able to do this and get out of there without any problem.
So I'm proud of them.
Emotionally, what did you think about the evacuation and the war was coming to an end and you're evacuating everybody out?
Well, I hated to see us desert the Vietnamese Army because
I had seen what communism would do.
I saw, for instance, what the North Vietnamese did in Hue Phu Bai during the Tet Offensive.
All of the Vietnamese that were working with us then, I shouldn't say all, but many of them were killed.
They had their hands cut off.
There were all kinds of atrocities that were
committed by the North Vietnamese and the Viet Cong during the Tet Offensive.
Well, there was no reason to believe that anything less than that was going to occur when the North Vietnamese took over.
So yes, I had great sympathy for the people in the South Vietnamese Army and
The civilians, of course, that had been a part of our effort there, I knew that they were going to be mistreated badly.
But you can't really dwell on things like that.
Your orders are to do a certain thing, so you do it.
And you just have to have faith that your government or something is going to
try to do the best they can in other areas.
And it was a sad day.
There's no doubt about that.
What were your feelings about the Vietnamese?
Well, the Vietnamese are good people.
The Oriental is not well understood by most Americans, and I don't claim to be an expert on that, but I have better
understanding, I guess, than the average person.
But he's a hardworking person.
He wants to be free as much as you and I do.
But I think because they are basically a peaceable people who work hard, then they're more apt to be
taken over by a group such as the communists.
Because really all they want to do is work and be left alone.
So communism can come in with a few people and get organized and so forth and get control.
And that basically is what happened.
Now, there were crooks within the Vietnamese government.
There's crooks in any government.
There's, you know, graft.
There's greedy people.
There's people who see an opportunity to make a windfall.
And they did that.
But there was no more in the Vietnamese society than what there is ours.
They're basically good people.
And I would like to see that land be free one day.
I don't foresee that.
in the near future, but I would certainly like to see it.
How'd you feel about Army?
Well, they had the same problem that I alluded to that our Army had.
See, they started out with nothing in 1964.
Basically nothing.
that actually had started before that.
But the size of the Army prior to 64 was next to nothing.

They started drafting people, putting them in uniform, putting them in organizations, assigning people to command them that didn't know anything whatsoever about military, and giving them a ill-defined job and mission
And then why should anybody be surprised that they performed in a very poor manner?
We started giving them advisors and so forth.
And again, General Schwarzkopf alluded to this in his book.
When they had good commanders, they had good units.
When they had bad commanders,
They had bad units.
If you had a battalion commander that did not know what to do or how to do it, what can you expect of him?
And so being as they started from nothing and mobilized to a rather large force for them, you have to assume that a lot of the commanders were politically appointed.
It's that simple.
And you know, you take a person who's inept, and today he's a civilian, tomorrow he's a major commanding an ARVN battalion, he's still inept.
If he's lucky, he would get a good advisor and would be smart enough to listen to him.
If he didn't get all of his people killed in the meantime, he would eventually develop into a reasonable unit.
But you compare them to a Marine battalion, for instance, and there would be no comparison.
They didn't know how to use supporting arms, for instance.
And of course, their artillerymen
were equally ill-prepared.
So for a long time, they could call for artillery support.
And because it had to go through so many layers to get approval to include civilians, that by the time they'd get a fire mission approved, there wouldn't be any point to fire it.
The enemy's gone.
So they worked under some terrible restrictions that we did not work under.
So I think before we judged them too severely, all those things had to be taken into consideration.
They worked under conditions that made it almost impossible most of the time for them to succeed.
How did your views change on the Vietnamese during the course of the war?
Well, I don't know as it did.
I could recognize from the outset that they were... Now, when you say Vietnamese, do you mean the army or the...
The South Vietnamese, just the people.
The people.
I don't know as it changed.
I respected them.
They're different people.
Their religion is different.
Their culture is different.
I did not understand much of their culture and most of their religion.
And I'm sure they didn't understand mine.
But they're good people and all they wanted was to be left alone to live.
That's all they wanted.
The communists wouldn't do it and there were times I'm sure when they thought we were kind of being strong armed
in our support of them.
But you have to realize, when you're the 800-pound gorilla, and that's what we were, you go into an area, you do a lot of damage.
We tore roads up.
We tore cemeteries up.
Not intentionally.
But you move a large force through, you move tanks through, the terrain was such that it just wasn't built for armies like we were.
I'm sure they got mad at us.
I'm sure there's times when I would get a little upset with them when I couldn't understand, here I am over here trying to save your country and you're concerned about
Me knocking this fence down to your house or something.
You can't take a tank that's eight foot wide through a road that's six foot wide without tearing something up.
If you believe that you've got to get through there, then you're going to go through there.
But my view of the Vietnamese people didn't change.
They're good people.
They were in a terrible situation.
Most of us are good people.
We were in a terrible situation.
We were trying to make the best of them.
A bad situation.
See, in almost every other war that we've ever fought, the non-combatants got out of the way and let the combatants fight.
But they didn't do that in this war.
Uh,

When, for instance, when my unit had responsibility for the highway, we would often, not often, every night, we would go out with ambush patrols, which would, in many cases, be 200 yards outside of a village where 300 or 400 people were living and sleeping that night.
Or we might go out, as we often did, and set up an ambush patrol in one of their cemeteries and wait for a Viet Cong patrol to come through.
Because that's the way the terrain and so forth was.
And I'm sure they were upset with us, and I'm sure there were times when I was upset with them.
How did your views about the South Vietnamese Army change over the course of the war?
Well, I think in many cases the poor commanders were weeded out and better commanders evolved.
So they actually became a more effective combat force.
But I found it strange, for instance, that they furnished liaison officers to us.
That about once a month, my liaison officer would want to go home for three or four days while the war was going on.
Look at it from his standpoint.
Lord, this war had been going on for seven or eight years then and might very well go on for another seven or eight years.
And yes, he had a family maybe 60 to 100 kilometers off.
Why wouldn't he want to go?
All things considered, I think they did pretty well.
One of the factors that's often lost when people start trying to
judge and put a handle on that is a conventional army fighting a guerrilla army is a mess at best.
First of all, a conventional army usually is heavy.
It's got lots of equipment, trucks, helicopters, guns, so forth.
And when that's the case, then
you're going to be pretty stationary.
A guerrilla army can come and go as they please.
They can just, you can see guerrillas one minute in an area.
You can send people over there and they've evaporated.
They've become part of the village.
But that
That regular army that's trying to fight him is always there.
He's always visible.
It's tough.
And there have been very, very few occasions in history where a guerrilla army has not actually, in the end, come out on top.
It's just the nature of the beast.
It's tough.
How were women treated from what you saw over there?
Now, do you mean the Vietnamese women?
Vietnamese women.
Well, there again, this was a subject that was constantly talked about in my view.
There was never any doubt in anybody's mind as to what I expected.
The dumbest private in my battalion knew that if he mistreated or if he tried to rape or steal or anything like that, that I would lock his butt up so quick it would make his head swim.
No ifs, ands, or buts about it.
So as a result, we didn't have any trouble.
First of all, when we were in the Waifu Bay area, we were so busy that it is just unreal.
We were probably taking care of what at least three battalions should have had.
And so my troops were so busy that when they
were given an hour off, they slept.
Because we were patrolling most of the day and all of the night.
And so what little bit of time that they had off, they slept.
But they also knew that there was not going to be any room for error.
as it related to treating those people with dignity.
And so they did.
The truth matters, I don't recall ever having any problems reported to me.
And believe me, we worked closely enough with the village chiefs and so forth, that if there was a problem, we had a technique of them getting the word to us quickly what was going on.
But the key to it is this.

My people knew because this sort of thing was discussed, I would say, at least three or four times a week in the battalion commander's conference where all of his staff and his company commanders were present.
These sort of things were covered, and then it went downhill that we didn't have a problem.

Now also, we had a system where when replacements came in, they were not sent down to the rifle companies until they had gone through an orientation program, part of which involved my telling them what would be done and what would not be done.
So there was no doubt as to whether everybody had the word that this sort of stuff would not be tolerated
that we would respect them as people, that we respect their religion and all of its symbols and so forth.
So but I put that the leadership, you know, that's the reason for having off is so that the will of the commander is is transmitted right down to the lowest level and then
You know, the last leadership technique is supervise.
And the brand, the newest second lieutenant that I had knew that his primary job was to see that what I wanted done was done.
And that I would nail his hide to the wall if it was not done.
So you didn't tolerate any form of racism?
None whatsoever.
Did you allow to call the Vietnamese people by racial slurs or anything like that?
Well, no.
It was not officially allowed.
But now, I'm not naive.
That goes on today in our society.
And you can keep a rein on it, but you cannot stop it.
But as long as they know there's a rain on it, then it's not good.
It'll never get you in trouble.
But, yeah, there's some, I'm sure there is.
How did we lose the war?
We didn't lose the war.
We lost the will to fight a war.
And there's a difference.
The will to fight the war was a political thing.
The war is a military thing.
Now, when we lost the will as a nation to do what was necessary from the military standpoint, then it was just a matter of time until inevitably it was going to crumble.
But it's like taking bricks out of a wall.
You can take so many bricks out in what used to be a formidable
thing becomes a menace.
It'll fall on you, will not protect you from anything after so many bricks have been taken out.
And that is precisely what happened.
Was the war a mistake?
No.
Why?
Anything that is judged after the game is over
is going to be judged very unfairly.
President Eisenhower was the first one to get us involved in Vietnam.
A lot of people don't realize that.
Then came President John Kennedy who started to accelerate all this.
In a perfect world
a person in responsibility such as President Kennedy or so forth would have perfect information on which to base a decision to do something.
And hence, whatever decision he made would probably be perfect.
But that, well, there never has been such a situation and there never will be.
But I don't recall really what
the intelligence was.
But I was on Okinawa in 1961.
And I recall the intelligence briefings that we were getting then as it related to Laos, which was really more important than Vietnam at that time, and also then Vietnam.
We followed it very closely.
But some people say that military intelligence is an oxymoron.
Well, that's not true, of course.
But intelligence really starts out as just a lot of information.
And again, it's usually provided by people that have a vested interest.
Anytime you get information or advice from someone with a vested interest, you have a slanted interest.
bit of information.
And if you act on information that is less than perfect, then your action is going to be less than perfect.
I truly believe with all my heart that President Kennedy, President Johnson was provided the best available information
As to whether or not it was misinterpreted, either on the military level or on the political level, I don't know.
I'm sure that they made decisions that they thought was best not only for this country as it relates to meeting our worldwide responsibility, but best for Vietnam.
Some of them turned out not to be good decisions.
But if there's any one thing that you learn
Once a decision has been made on what you believe to be the best available information, go with it.
If the information changes, then change.
But a lot of these things can be equated to launching a bullet.
Once that thing has been launched, it has a life of its own.
And watch out down range.
And sometimes that's about all you can do is say, look out.
You may have been wrong.
And the best you can do is say, look out.
Here it comes.
Drop that bomb.
You truly believe it's on target when you drop that bomb.
But it does not always hit its target.
Now, are you going to go back and second guess yourself later on as to whether or not you should drop that bomb?
If you do, you will lose your mind.
People have talked about Vietnam saying that it's the war that we can't forget because we learn so much about ourselves.
What kind of things did you learn about the human nature?
I learned that people can be very mean to other people.
I don't know what you've read on, and I keep referring to this My Lai Massacre, but here was a platoon of U.S. Army forces that went into a village
men, women, and children of in a ditch and systematically shot them.
Now that absolutely boggles my mind.
So what did I learn?
I learned that we can be a very cruel people.
I know that that's not an isolated incident.
That lesser things happened all over.
My discussions with my contemporaries when I was on the Army staff showed me that, yes, that happened more often than we'd like to believe.
But again, I put that on the leaders.
His company commander and his battalion commander, I assigned equal responsibility with that of Lieutenant Kelly because

If Cali had been properly led, he would have known that had he done something like that, that his company commander, his battalion commander, would have nailed his hide to the wall, he wouldn't have done it.
But the potential for doing it is there.
We are a mean people.
The Vietnamese are mean people.
They did the same thing to their people.
They would go into villages that had been sympathetic to the vehicle.
And they'd go in, and they would do this very same thing.
They'd wipe them out.
So we are mean people.
I learned that.
I learned also that we are very compassionate people.
Most of us want to do good.
There's good and bad within all of us.
Most of the time, good wins.
Sometimes bad wins.
Some people allowed their pride and their ego to do things which were not in the best interest of either their units or the Vietnamese.
The desire to succeed.
They used to have what they called a body count, which in many units was a big deal.
It wasn't with us.
I can say that coming from above, I was never pressed for body count.
In talking with my contemporaries that I knew in the Pentagon, it was a constant thing.
So if it sounds as though I'm prejudiced, I guess I am.
We were better led.
Just that simple.
How do you feel about the media coverage that went on during the war?
I would assign, on a scale of 1 to 10, I would assign the media coverage as a minus 10.
There obviously are good people in the media.
But for every good person, there were 10
who were looking for one thing and one thing only, something that would gain a headline, whether it was two minutes on the television or were 10 column inches in a paper.
Just as a for instance, on the
